Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the hum of the factory floor below a constant reminder of my responsibilities. As a machine repairer, I knew the big shutdown was next week—my chance to finally get ahead on maintenance. The machines had been running hot, and I’d already made a list of parts to clean and replace. But my mind kept drifting to the email from my mentor. She’d suggested some articles to read, not urgent, but she always noticed who took her advice seriously. I wanted to impress her, to show I was committed to learning, even if the deadline was weeks away. 

But every time I tried to focus on the reading, I’d remember the machines—how a missed detail now could mean a breakdown later. Yet, if I put off the reading, would my mentor think I wasn’t dedicated? The expectations tugged at me from both sides, each role demanding my attention, each with its own consequences. I stared at the unread articles and the maintenance checklist, feeling the pressure build, unsure which responsibility to tackle first.
